Posts.Content: kdoole01 wrote: Has anyone out there had Pulse Dye Laser Tx to their previously radiated breast for telangiectasia that developed as a post radiation?  At 6 years post RT, my team talked me into receiving this laser tx to the underside of my reconstructed breast (b/l silicone implants, R side s/p RT).  Unfortunately, I developed 2 small non-healing wounds thru which my silicone implant eventually came thru, requiring removal of the implant.  I have search all over the Internet to see if there are any other patients out there like me, or who have had this tx.  Thanks for responding! Dx 10/10/2006, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 7/28 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 10/20/2006 Lymph node removal: Left, Right, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Targeted Therapy 12/12/2006 Avastin (bevacizumab) Chemotherapy 12/12/2006 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel), Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide) Hormonal Therapy 3/14/2007 Surgery 4/13/2007 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Radiation Therapy 5/5/2007 Breast, Lymph nodes Surgery 5/6/2008 Prophylactic ovary removal Hormonal Therapy 5/7/2008 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 6/30/2010 Reconstruction (left) Surgery 7/3/2013 Reconstruction (right) Surgery 10/18/2013 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Laser Tx for Telangiectasia from RT kdoole01 coraleliz

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2013 05:15PM kdoole01 wrote: That stinks that you have bone mets for sure! MarieK has some good advice and you will get your "plan of attack" in order to settle in for the marathon. I once met a lady at chemo who told me that she had just had her 7th recurrence! I was aghast, but she then said to me "I have lived over 25 years with breast cancer. Back in those days they didn't tell you anything and you just did what you were told to do. Now I'm and old lady (as she laughed out loud) and bring my own hot chocolate to chemo and things to keep me busy while I am here...but I am still here!" And I'll tell you something...she looked damn good! So I know that people are put into our paths to teach us a lesson. Cancer is a marathon...so you need to pace yourself. Give it the time and attention it needs, but get back you your like asap. It doesn't deserve the best part of you, so give it as little as possible! Good luck!
Posts.Title: Tumor markers up Maureen813 Maureen813

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2013 01:10PM kdoole01 wrote: You are always a Stage IIIer. You just have a little extra baggage. Seriously, your staging always remains your original staging.
